header.title: El Zóhar: Anotaciones al Comentario de Rabí Yehuda Ashlag

central_thesis: The Zohar, as interpreted by Baal HaSulam and Rav Laitman, is presented as the ultimate guide for humanity's spiritual correction and ascent to the Creator. This path involves transforming inherent egoistic desires into altruistic ones through systematic Kabbalistic study and practice, thereby achieving complete equivalence of form and unity with the Divine.

structure_content.summary: Introduces Rabbi Shimon Bar-Yochai (Rashbi) as the concealed author of the Zohar, later revealed by Baal HaSulam and Rav Laitman. Highlights the Zohar's crucial role in spiritual redemption and the author's lineage within this Kabbalistic tradition.

Explains the Zohar's multi-layered language (Kabbalistic, spiritual, narrative, judicial) and its focus on man's internal spiritual state. Details the Zohar's textual structure and how the commentary integrates Baal HaSulam's work to make it accessible for modern students seeking spiritual advancement.

Crucial glossary of Kabbalistic terms used throughout the text, such as Sefirot, Partzufim, Or (Light), Kli (Vessel), Zivug (Spiritual Copulation), MAN, MAD, Katnut (Small State), Gadlut (Great State), and Tzimtzum (Restriction), defining them precisely according to the author's system for operative understanding.

Interprets 'The Rose' as Malchut (Assembly of Israel) and her composition of judgment and mercy, surrounded by thirteen attributes of mercy. Explains the concept of egoism ('yo') versus altruism, the necessity of conscious desire transformation, and the 'point in the heart' as the spiritual starting point. Details the Partzuf and Sefirot structure, including Gadlut (great state) through Masaj (screen) and Or Jozer (reflected light).

Connects the 'shoots of the flowers' to the Patriarchs and the creation days to Sefirot, illustrating the spiritual development of Nukva (Malchut) from Katnut to Gadlut. Emphasizes the role of MAN (prayer) in elevating Nukva and receiving Or Jojmá (Light of Wisdom). Symbolism of colors (red/white) in the rose is discussed.

Explores the creation of Heaven and Earth through Sefirot and human correction. Defines MI and MA as spiritual levels. Describes 'apertura de los ojos' (Malchut's position in AA's Rosh) for receiving Or Jojmá. Explains BARÁ (creating) as Binah generating ZON and highlights the importance of MAN (prayer) in elevating Sefirot to receive Or Jojmá.

Continuation of the creation narrative, focusing on the revelation of the 'Supreme Secret' and the path to Or Neshamá and Or Jayá. Clarifies the role of 'ÉLEH' and 'MI' in the name Elokim and their relation to various Sefirot and the correction process, stressing that the Zohar's teachings are spiritual, not physical.

structure_content.chapter_title: La madre presta a la hija sus vestiduras
structure_content.summary: Details Malchut (the daughter) receiving attributes and 'jewels' (Or Jojmá and Or Neshamá) from Binah (the mother) to achieve perfection. Explains Malchut's transformation into a masculine principle (Adón) and the concept of 'MI' (Binah) as a state of perfect reception.

Elaborates on the spiritual significance of Hebrew letters as Kli (vessels) and attributes, each representing a stage of correction. Discusses the Gematria of letter combinations and their role in creation and correction, emphasizing Malchut as the central part of creation.
Analyzes the letter Tav as representing truth and the Creator's seal, yet also linked to 'death' due to its association with strict judgment. Explains the purpose and correction of impure forces.

Explores Shin's representation of truth and 'Shaday' (God's name), symbolizing divine limitation. Contrasts it with Tav, explaining how impure forces (Kof and Resh) can corrupt Shin's truth into 'Shéker' (falsehood) and how these forces originate.

Details Kof and Resh as embodying the impure, 'cold' side of creation. Explains their appropriation of Shin to form 'KeSHeR' (connection), allowing impure forces to sustain themselves by adhering to pure ones, and the resulting deformation of the Creator's seal.

Describes Tzadi as representing Tzadikim (the righteous) and Yesod. Explains its initial concealment and connection to Nun and Yud, and the 'male and female' aspects of creation, emphasizing the need for 'face-to-face' union for true creation.

Focuses on Pey symbolizing 'liberation' (Pdut) and its connection to future redemption. Contrasts it with Ayin (humility), discussing Pesha (sin) and Avón (iniquity), and Pey's role as Hod in ZA for receiving Or Jojmá.

Examines Samech as representing 'support' (Smijá) and Binah's mercy, safeguarding ZA and Malchut from falling into impure realms. Explains its importance in Katnut (small state) but its limitations in achieving complete perfection.

Presents Nun as representing 'great praises' (Norá Tehilot) and its connection to Guevurá in ZA. Discusses its ability to attract Or Jojmá in Gadlut (great state) but its unsuitability for creation due to its association with 'Nefilá' (fall).
Explores Mem as representing 'Mélej' (King) and Hesed in ZA, revealing Or Jojmá. Explains the necessity of Mem uniting with Lamed (Binah) and Kaf (Malchut) to fully manifest MéLeJ.

Describes Kaf as 'Kavod' (Glory) and its connection to Keter of AVI and Binah of AA. Discusses its 'fall' from the 'throne' (Briá) due to Mem's light, and its dual role as a 'throne' for ZA and a 'robe' or 'crown' for Malchut.

Examines Yud as the first letter of HaVaYaH, symbolizing Or Jojmá and the beginning of divine revelation. Discusses its arguments for creation, the Creator's refutation due to its self-perfection, and its connection to Tzimtzum (restriction) and the four types of spiritual correction.

Interprets BERESHIT as the wisdom upon which ZA (the world) rests, connecting it to Binah (Or Jojmá). Discusses the six supreme attributes (VAK of Binah) and the ascent of ZON to AVI to receive Or Jojmá. Explains 'BARÁ SHIT' as creating six attributes and the dual meaning of Bereshit.

Explains BERESHIT as referring to VAK of Binah, with GAR hidden. Discusses the Second Restriction and Malchut's elevation to NE (Nikvey Einaim) as the 'lock,' while Atéret Yesod acts as the 'key' to reveal Or Jojmá, emphasizing altruistic intent.

Presents Abraham as the attribute of Hesed, opening the 'locked doors' of Jojmá and revealing concealed wisdom (BARÁ). Explores the production of 'generations' linked to Malchut's descent and Or Jojmá revesting Or Jasadim. Discusses the Partzuf ZA and Sefirot JaGaT/NeHY structure.

Describes Rabbi Hiya's vision of Malchut ('dust of the earth') consuming souls and the need for spiritual correction to transform egoism. Explains the fragmentation of Adam's soul, reincarnation, and 'tears' (Or Jojmá without Or Jasadim) falling into Malchut. Emphasizes the goal of complete soul correction.

Interprets the 'donkey driver' as a spiritual force (Rabbi Hamnuna-Saba) guiding souls. Explains 'Shabatot' as two states (ZA and Malchut) and the three stages of spiritual growth (Ibur, Yenika, Mojin). The donkey (Jamor) symbolizes matter (Jómer) that must be controlled through spiritual work.

Explores the 'two points' (Binah and Malchut) as the foundation of Jojmá and 'fear of the Creator' as the 'beginning of wisdom.' Discusses their unity in BERESHIT and the process of transforming negative perceptions into knowledge and sweetness as paths to the Creator.

Describes Shavuot as the 'night of the bride' (Malchut uniting with ZA) and the importance of Torah study (Prophets, Sacred Writings) as 'jewels' for her correction during 'exile' (concealment). Explains the 'new Jupá' created by the righteous through their spiritual work.

Reiterates the creation of Heaven and Earth by 'MI BARÁ ÉLEH' (Binah creating ZON). Emphasizes the spiritual unity needed and the prohibition against 'other gods' (egoistic forces). Discusses 'translation' (Aramaic) as a lower spiritual language and the spiritual 'lands' related to Malchut. Explores Cain and Abel as spiritual events of mixing pure and impure forces.

structure_content.chapter_title: Entre todos los sabios de las naciones del mundo, no hay nadie como Tú
structure_content.summary: Examines the philosophical debate between human reason (represented by 'wise of the nations') and faith (Israel). Emphasizes that true understanding and resemblance to the Creator come through faith and Mitzvot, leading to spiritual achievements like 'raising the dead' (correcting egoism) and 'bringing rain' (Or Jasadim).

Highlights the power of Torah study and prayer for spiritual correction, emphasizing internal transformation over external acts. Discusses prayer as a desire for change and connection, and the progressive ascent through spiritual degrees, leading to unity with the Creator.

Deepens the concept of prayer as a sincere, internal desire (MAN) for spiritual correction, transforming egoistic desires into altruistic ones. Describes the spiritual stages of ascent (Katnut, Gadlut) and the importance of humility, fear, and love in this process.

Continues to detail the spiritual ascent through prayer, describing how the human soul (Malchut) progresses through 'firmaments' (spiritual levels) with the help of various 'governors' (Sefirot). Explains the interaction of Or Jasadim and Or Jojmá and the critical role of intention in overcoming egoism.

Introduces the Mandamientos (Commandments) as spiritual principles for human correction, starting with 'fear of the Creator' and 'love of the Creator'. Explains how these commandments represent stages of spiritual development and the transformation of desires from egoistic to altruistic. Discusses the significance of various letters of the Hebrew alphabet in these commandments.

Focuses on the First Commandment, 'fear of the Creator,' as the foundation of all wisdom and the gateway to faith. Explains that this fear is not based on worldly consequences but on the recognition of the Creator's absolute greatness and power. Emphasizes that perfect faith is impossible without true fear.

Details the Second Commandment, 'love of the Creator,' emphasizing perfect, unconditional love. Explains that true love persists even through suffering, transcending conditional love based on receiving good. Discusses the integration of fear and love to achieve perfect spiritual states.

Explores the Third Commandment: proclaiming the unity of the Creator ('Shemá Israel: Adonay Eloheinu, Adonay Ejad'). Emphasizes the spiritual act of uniting the six superior extremities of ZA with Malchut, extending the sound of 'UNO' to signify the reception of Or Jojmá.

Focuses on the Fourth Commandment: uniting HaVaYaH (ZA) and Elokim (Nukva) to achieve perfect oneness. Explains this union as the reception of GAR (Or Jojmá) in ZON, symbolizing the harmony between white light (ZA) and black light (Malchut), making them a single celestial body.

Addresses the Fifth Commandment: 'Let the waters teem with living creatures' (procreation and multiplication). Spiritually, this means transforming Yesod of ZA into an inexhaustible source of new souls (Or Jojmá) and correcting the sacred covenant (circumcision) and rejection of Orlá (impure desires).

Expands on the Sixth Commandment, procreation, emphasizing it as an act of continuous spiritual growth. It involves overcoming egoism and unifying with the Creator to generate 'new souls' (NaRaN) and 'celestial forces,' symbolizing the complete correction of Adam's sin.

Focuses on the Seventh Commandment: circumcision on the eighth day. Spiritually, this is the removal of the impure 'prepucio' (Orlá) from Malchut, enabling the soul to receive Or Jayá and achieve the 'eighth degree,' symbolizing spiritual purity and union with Binah.

Addresses the Eighth Commandment: to love the stranger. Spiritually, this means integrating purified egoistic desires ('strangers') under the wings of the Shejiná (Malchut). This process allows the 'stranger' to receive light (Or Jayá) and eventually become an integral part of Israel, symbolizing the transformation of lower desires.

Focuses on the Ninth Commandment: showing mercy to the needy and providing food. Spiritually, this is understood as achieving the 'image and likeness of Adam' ('Hagamos al Hombre') by balancing masculine (rich/giving) and feminine (poor/receiving) attributes, especially through charity and compassion.

Details the Tenth Commandment: wearing Tefillin. Spiritually, Tefillin represent the 'Supreme Head' (HaVaYaH), containing sacred names and allowing man to align his thoughts and actions with the Creator. The correction involves uniting the male and female aspects (TzéLeM) within oneself.

Explains the Eleventh Commandment: tithing the produce of the land. Spiritually, this means separating sacred sparks of Light from impure forces in the 'food' (Light reception). The practice of tithing (giving the tenth part) helps to elevate MAN and receive Or Jayá, symbolizing the purification of desires.

Addresses the Twelfth Commandment: offering the first fruits. Spiritually, this commandment prohibits the egoistic reception of the highest Light (Or Jayá) until complete correction. It emphasizes the need to avoid the 'sin of Adam' by not consuming the 'first fruits' for self-benefit.

Focuses on the Thirteenth Commandment: redeeming the firstborn. Spiritually, this act weakens the 'angel of death' (egoism) and strengthens the 'angel of life' (altruism), symbolizing the transformation of negative forces into positive ones. It prefigures the final correction where egoism becomes a vessel for greater Light.

Details the Fourteenth Commandment: observing Shabbat. Spiritually, Shabbat is a state of complete rest from correction, where divine Light descends and all actions are perfected. It involves 'observing' (receiving Or Jojmá) and 'sanctifying' (receiving Or Jasadim) Shabbat, uniting the worlds from egoism to altruism.

key_concepts.definition: The Book of Splendor, a foundational text of Kabbalah, containing esoteric teachings on the nature of God, the origin of the universe, the souls, and the correction process. It is viewed as a guide for humanity's spiritual ascent.

A spiritual science focused on the systematic transformation of inherent egoistic desires into altruistic ones, aiming to achieve equivalence of form with the Creator. It is described as a practical method for understanding and living in harmony with the laws of the spiritual universe.

The ten divine emanations or attributes (Kéter, Jojmá, Biná, Jésed, Guevurá, Tiféret, Nétzaj, Hod, Yesod, and Maljut) through which the Infinite (Ein Sof) reveals itself and creates the worlds. They represent different spiritual degrees or qualities that human consciousness must attain.

Complete spiritual structures, each comprising ten Sefirot, functioning as integral spiritual objects or states. Key Partzufim include Adam Kadmón (AK), Árij Anpin (AA), Aba ve Ima (AVI), Zeir Anpin (ZA), and Nukva (Maljut). They are the 'faces' or aspects of the divine that reveal themselves through specific combinations of Sefirot.

Spiritual pleasure or sensation emanating from the Creator. It is differentiated into Or Jojmá (Light of Wisdom, associated with the pleasure of reception) and Or Jasadim (Light of Mercy, associated with the pleasure of bestowal or altruism). The goal is to receive Or Jojmá while being clothed in Or Jasadim, meaning receiving for the purpose of bestowal.

The desire or spiritual receptacle of a being. Initially egoistic, it must be corrected through spiritual work to become altruistic and capable of receiving Light 'in benefit of the Creator.' Desires and aspirations are considered 'Kli' only when corrected for altruistic reception.

A spiritual force of resistance (anti-egoistic force) against receiving Light for self-benefit. It is developed through conscious effort and allows for the reception of Light with the intention of bestowal. The strength of the Masaj determines the quantity of Light that can be received altruistically.

The contraction or limitation of the infinite light to create space for finite beings. The First Restriction (Tzimtzum Álef) prohibits receiving Light for self-benefit. The Second Restriction (Tzimtzum Bet) involves Biná, ZA, and Maljut not receiving Light in their respective internal desires for self-benefit, allowing for the possibility of later altruistic reception.

A spiritual connection or union between a Superior Partzuf and an inferior Partzuf, or between masculine and feminine aspects, leading to the transmission and reception of Light. This union is not physical but a spiritual alignment of attributes and intentions.

The sincere request, prayer, or aspiration from an inferior spiritual degree or entity to a Superior one for spiritual correction and elevation. It is the 'awakening from below' that elicits a response from the Creator.

The divine response or flow of Light and spiritual forces from a Superior spiritual degree to an inferior one, granted in response to MAN. It represents the 'awakening from above' that provides the necessary strength for correction.

The tenth and lowest Sefirah, representing the ultimate creation and the sum of all human souls. It is fundamentally an egoistic desire to receive pleasure, but its correction is the central purpose of creation. Often referred to as the 'Assembly of Israel' or 'Earth,' it must be transformed to receive Light altruistically.

More than just linguistic symbols, each Hebrew letter represents a specific spiritual attribute, force, or degree of Light within the Kabbalistic system. They are the 'building blocks' of creation and reveal the Creator's governance and methods for spiritual attainment through their forms, numerical values (Gematria), and combinations.

practical_system.description: The core practical system presented is a structured path for spiritual self-correction and union with the Creator. This involves the systematic transformation of inherent egoistic desires (Kelim) into altruistic ones, aligning human will with the divine attribute of bestowal. The process is a gradual ascent through 125 spiritual degrees or 'rooms,' each requiring the development of a 'screen' (Masaj) to resist egoistic reception of Light (Or Jojmá) and cultivate the intention to receive 'in benefit of the Creator.' The ultimate goal is equivalence of form with the Creator, leading to infinite pleasure, knowledge, and life. This is achieved through specific spiritual 'actions' which are internal transformations, not necessarily external rituals.
tools: Zohar and Kabbalistic Texts: Primary manuals for understanding spiritual structures, divine attributes, and the method of self-correction.
Spiritual Teacher (Rav): Essential guide for accurate interpretation and practical application of Kabbalistic principles.
Masaj (Screen): An internal faculty developed to resist egoistic reception of pleasure, allowing for altruistic reception.
MAN (Prayer/Aspiration): The inner force of longing and request for spiritual transformation.
Recognition of Egoism: Conscious identification and rejection of self-serving desires as obstacles to spiritual progress.
Hebrew Letters and Gematria: Sacred 'codes' representing spiritual attributes and levels, used for deep contemplative work and precise spiritual manipulation.
rituals: Torah Study (Limud Torah): Active engagement with Kabbalistic texts to transform egoistic desires and draw divine Light (MAD).
Prayer (MAN): Sincere, internal supplication and aspiration for spiritual correction, initiating the flow of divine assistance.
Circumcision (Brit Milá): Symbolically, the cutting off or rejection of egoistic desires (Orlá) to purify Malchut for altruistic reception.
Blessings: Specific internal states and invocations to draw and utilize divine Light and achieve spiritual elevation (e.g., morning blessings, Shabbat blessings).
Offerings/Sacrifices (Korbán): The internal act of rejecting egoistic desires and transforming impure intentions into altruistic ones, bringing one closer to the Creator.
Tefillin: Spiritual tools representing the four letters of HaVaYaH, used to align thoughts and actions with divine intent and manifest different Lights and corrections in the head and hand.
Shabbat Observance: A spiritual state of rest and unity, where corrections are completed, and the divine Light is fully revealed, embodying freedom from egoistic struggles.

relevant_quotes.text: En el siglo II de nuestra era vivió un hombre único al cual le fue conferida la sabiduría espiritual que los cabalistas habían acumulado a lo largo de 3 000 años: Rabí Shimon Bar-Yojay (Rashbí). Él dejó constancia por escrito de dicha sabiduría para posteriormente ocultarla, pues la humanidad aún no estaba preparada para ello. Hoy, sin embargo, nos encontramos listos para la revelación de El Libro del Zóhar.

El Libro del Zóhar es la obra más misteriosa y, al mismo tiempo, la más importante entre todos los libros de Cabalá. En los últimos años, poco a poco hemos ido comprobando que, aunque El Libro del Zóhar fue escrito dieciocho siglos atrás, en realidad fue compuesto pensando en nuestra época. Rabí Yehuda Ashlag (Baal HaSulam) lo abrió al gran público y dio nuevo brío a algo que, por tanto tiempo, habíamos alejado de nuestros corazones.
La profundidad de la sabiduría en El Libro del Zóhar está guardada bajo mil cerrojos.
Nuestra generación se encuentra a las puertas de la redención, ojalá sepamos cómo diseminar la sabiduría de lo oculto a las masas.

La Cabalá tiene por objeto de estudio lo único que fue creado, lo único que existe aparte del Creador: el “yo” del hombre. Y lo investiga. Esta ciencia descompone el “yo” en partes, explica la estructura y atributos de cada una de ellas, y el propósito de su creación. La Cabalá explica cómo cada parte del “yo” humano, denominado “el alma”, puede ser transformado de modo que podamos alcanzar la meta de la creación: un estado deseado tanto por el Creador como por el hombre y que ha de ser alcanzado de manera consciente.

Maljut es la criatura: el deseo egoísta de recibir placer, de disfrutar la Luz del Creador. Este deseo de gozar de la Luz del Creador o, lo que es lo mismo, del propio Creador, constituye la esencia de Maljut. Nosotros somos partes de Maljut.

El Partzuf espiritual tiene una cabeza, lugar donde se toman las decisiones. En ella únicamente se encuentran los deseos que de antemano es sabido que poseen pantalla (resistencia a los deseos) para utilizarlos de manera espiritual, altruistamente, y darles la vuelta transformándolos de “para uno mismo” a “para el Creador”. Si el hombre cumple todos los 613 Mandamientos de la Torá y los 7 Mandamientos de las naciones del mundo (620 Mandamientos en total), ascenderá 620 grados consiguiendo así la adhesión total con el Creador.

El hombre debe aspirar al Creador en su corazón y deseos, para que aparezcan en él intenciones que le lleve a las correcciones en todos los estados espirituales descritos en esta oración, para que su boca y su corazón (deseos) se conviertan en un único todo y sus labios no hablen contra los deseos de su corazón. Porque el Creador únicamente espera la sinceridad de nuestros deseos, a fin de complacerlos inmediatamente y llevarnos más cerca de Él.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book's relevance in Western Esotericism and Occultism lies in its modern, systematic interpretation of the Zohar, a foundational text of Kabbalah. It bridges traditional Jewish mysticism with contemporary understanding, offering a structured path for spiritual ascent focused on internal transformation. This approach contrasts with ceremonial magic, emphasizing the psychological and experiential aspects of occult practice through precise definitions of Sefirot, Partzufim, and the mechanics of divine light (Or) and vessels (Kli). For practitioners of Hermetic Qabalah, it provides a rigorous framework for understanding the underlying spiritual processes and the operative role of consciousness in manipulating these forces, particularly through the conscious cultivation of altruism (bestowal) over egoism (reception).
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book targets serious students of Kabbalah, ranging from beginners to advanced practitioners, who seek a deep, systematic understanding of its principles for spiritual self-correction and connection to the Divine. It is for those committed to an inner, transformative path, willing to engage with complex esoteric concepts, and who understand the necessity of learning directly from a qualified teacher within the Baal HaSulam lineage. It is not intended for casual readers or those seeking superficial or New Age interpretations of mysticism, but rather for individuals dedicated to a structured spiritual discipline.
